Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Consequences of Status Inconsistency.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1302715
PI: Shelley Correll
Co-PI: Alec Watts
Stanford University

Across the social sciences, research has demonstrated that status is an omnipresent and consequential cultural concept associated with both social categories (e.g., race, gender) and social roles (e.g., occupations). This dissertation research is concerned with the interactions of status, focusing specifically on the consequences of a person occupying a social role that is culturally associated with a level of generalized status, respect or esteem that is inconsistent with their social category. Examples of such individuals are black women engineers, stay-at-home dads, male secretaries, and college students who pursue majors atypical for their gender. This project refines the concept of status inconsistency and develops an original, general theoretical model of the consequences of occupying a status-inconsistent role. The project is centered on three primary research questions: 1) How does status inconsistency bias judgment? 2) What are the tangible consequences of these biases? And 3) In what ways do justifications for being status-inconsistent moderates these biases and consequences? The research will use social science experimental techniques to measure participants' perceptions, attitudes, and justifications of those responses in a variety of contexts.

Broader Impact
The contribution of this project is to develop a single, general model of how status inconsistency can shape an individual's experiences in a social role. The generalizability of the model allows for its applicability across a vast range of situations, such as diversity recruitment in higher education and high status occupations, as minority individuals are often status-inconsistent in these settings. As another example, stay-at-home dads are status-inconsistent and the negative social consequences men face as caretakers may be partly responsible for the dearth of men being more involved in housework and childcare. Thus, this project contributes to understanding inequalities in education, workplaces, and in homes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project introduced and tested a generalizable model of the effects of category-role status inconsistency on perceptions and anticipated behaviors. Category-role status inconsistency refers to an inconsistency between the status society affords a person's characteristics and the social role they occupy. Examples of status inconsistency include stay-at-home fathers, black women engineers, men secretaries, and college students who pursue majors atypical for their gender.

To formulate the model, this project synthesized social psychological literature on status (e.g., Berger et al. 1977), psychological literature on violating stereotypes (e.g., Rudman et al. 2012), and findings from in-depth ethnographies and experiments about the experiences of status-inconsistent individuals.  Doing so yielded a general, theoretical model that suggested answers to three primary research questions. First, how does status inconsistency bias judgment of status-inconsistent individuals? Second, what are the tangible consequences of these biases? Third, in what ways do justifications for being status-inconsistent moderate the biases and tangible consequences?

We conducted three experiments to test the model. Though consistent effects emerged within each experiment, few robust effects emerged to support the model’s generalizability.

For the first experiment, we conducted a series of pre-tests to assess how to operationalize status inconsistency. These pre-tests failed to yield clean operationalizations of categories and roles that could test the model in an ideal way. We nevertheless proceeded with the full experiments and interpreted the results with this caveat. In the full experiment, we tested perceptions of, and predicted behaviors towards, Hispanic-American women who are either news anchors (status-inconsistent) or fast food workers, relative to white men who are either fast food employees (status-inconsistent) or news anchors. The most robust finding was that status-inconsistent individuals are perceived as less prototypical than other members of their social category.

In a second experiment, we examined perceptions of, and behaviors towards, mothers who are employed (status inconsistency) or full-time caretakers, relative to fathers who are full-time caretakers (status inconsistency) or employed. This experiment provided more support than the first experiment for the model, primarily for stay-at-home fathers. Stay-at-home fathers were perceived as less competent, likeable, and prototypical than stay-at-home mothers. However, there was no evidence that these biases affected recommended role rewards or social distance preferences toward stay-at-home fathers.  Inconsistent with past research, we find that employed mothers were perceived as no less competent, likeable, or prototypical than employed fathers.   The justifications for being in the roles moderated these results. Being a stay-at-home parent for personal fulfillment increased likeability for stay-at-home moms and decreased likeability for stay-at-home dads, as we expected. It had no effect on employed parents.

In a final experiment, we attempted to disentangle the effects of status and gender-typing of an occupation on biases and behaviors toward status-inconsistent individuals.  Participants were randomly paired with a fictitious partner who was either a man or a woman and either a Customer Support Assistant or a Senior Manager of Customer Relations at a company specializing either in women’s cosmetics or construction equipment. We found that being in a status-inconsistent or gender-inconsistent occupation had little effect on perceptions and behaviors. A few significant effects emerged, however. We found that women’s gender-inconsistency (working at a construction company) reduced perceived competence, while men’s gender-inconsistency (working at a cosmetic’s company) did not. We also found some evidence that, though the women targets in this study were liked more than other targets, this was less the case for status-inconsistent women. This suggests that being in a high status role may reduce perceptions of a woman’s likeability.

Across the different studies, there is little evidence for a general model of status inconsistency, suggesting that such a model may be too general for the scope of this project. Categories and roles are diverse and associated with numerous cultural associations which shape perceptions in different ways. As a result, a single, generalizable model is difficult to formulate.

Nevertheless, one consistent pattern that emerged from these studies is the strong prototypicality bias caused by men’s gender violations. Across the studies we found that men in status-inconsistent roles were perceived as less typical men than men in status-consistent roles. The consistency of this effect across these different studies provides strong evidence that men’s gender violations reduce prototypicality. We found little evidence that women’s gender violations resulted in such a consistent prototypicality bias. Given the robustness of this pattern of effects, future research should consider this bias when assessing the effects of status inconsistency on perceptions.
